title: This balance issue is pushing me away from league.
body: Tired of riot acknowledging the fact that certain champions are stronger than they should be with nothing being done about it. It's making me not want to play this game anymore.

It's not about stronger in the LCS.  Its about consistent and not easily counterpicked.  The professionals keep their jobs by winning, which means that a risky pick could cost them their jobs.  Therefore they need to go with champs that fit into just about any team composition.  And when you have to be able to play almost entirely by instinct since you won't have time to think, you have to have a champ where you've played/practiced them for hundreds and even thousands of hours.  

So most pros really have a champ pool of maybe 5 champs they are willing/able to play in a game unless the team plans ahead for some kind of unusual comp.  And those 5 have to be generalists for the most part.

Therefore we get the Lee Sin/Jarvin IV/Vi jungle because all 3 are generalist junglers with a lot of utility.  Are there other junglers who could work.  Certainly, but they might not fit the comp should the team need to change tactics in the middle of a match, so, the pros go with the same champs.

Of course, the best solution would be to make it so there are no generalists, but that would anger the pros who need those champions.  They don't want to find their team saying "I'm sorry, but we aren't renewing your contract." and to make sure that happens they need to win.  That requires having the generalist champs available to give them the best chance to win.

Needing to think about your picks and bans and actually having a diverse and flexible champion pool *should* be how you make it to pro status, and if you can't keep up, you shouldn't be there. No champion should fit into almost every mold with strong results and little penalty, that's where this whole issue stems from. 

Adjusting and adapting is so much more fun to watch than Lee sin, Jarvan, and Vi, 24/7.

Could you imagine how much better this game would be with more bans? or with a better balance system? We'd probably see more diversity or maybe not who knows. Pro's need to have a bigger champion pool, not stick with the same champions and face role it. I'm not saying they aren't good, I'm just saying as a pro I expect more from them.

In game numbers are entirely arbitrary as are the words buff and nerf.  In reality there is a baseline around stats and durations.  For example, 500 ap or ad is about normal near end game, move speeds are all similar ranges etc.  Stuns rarely last more than a couple seconds and so on.

Champions are all balanced relative to eachother.  In this sense the problem is they dunk certain champions into the nerfbasket, but others remain at or above the baseline creating wildly large gaps in their consistency.  Champs that have lots of consistency consequently have the most of what everyone complains about...  that is having very little counterplay.

>For example, 500 ap or ad is about normal near end game, move speeds are all similar ranges etc.
> 

I just want to point out that it use to be that AP always reached the end game with higher AP than AD champions had AD. More and more AD scaling skills have been getting added to the game over the past few years, {{champion:92}}{{champion:238}} {{champion:91}} , and for some reason AD has been reaching the same numbers as AP. Yet AP still doesn't scale their basic attacks directly with their AP or have a stat like crit, capped CDR at 40% compared to 2.5sec atk speed (which also scales naturally), and spell vamp was gutted years ago compared to lifesteal which with a {{item:3074}} or {{item:3072}} a champion can heal to almost full in a single minion wave.

I can agree with this. The balance of this game is nonexistent.

I'm really tired of seeing the same champions being selected in Ranked because they are clearly stronger stat-wise and kit-wise.

Nobody picks anything else because they aren't as strong and/or counter who the enemy team has selected. People also don't play who they find fun because of non-viability and instead play what can take X champ on the enemy team down the quickest possible.

For example, you never see the enemy team select Thresh as support and your support say "Wow, they just picked Thresh... Now who should I pick... Hmm... Taric!". Nobody plays the old and dusty champs because they stand no chance and/or have very little to offer.

If all champs or the majority were balanced, it wouldn't matter as much that "X champ counters X champ" and would be more based on skill. I don't feel anymore like I'm playing "League of Legends" and feel more like I'm now playing "League of Counters".

But I think the 'lc$bigplays' thing is total bullshit. Oriana saw huge play, and made huge plays. She got gutted. Hardly playable due to the mana regen nerfs forcing assassins into the front of the meta again. I would say that League is shifting away from being a strategy game, focusing more into an action game. The meta shifts reflect it. The only viable champion right now still based in a strategy design, is Nasus, who's focus is completely on scaling into the lategame and stomping. He is not skill based, he's planning and execution based.

This is why I wish Nemesis mode was permanent. This week I got to do stuff I haven't in years. I've played as Taric, Zac, Urgot, Nunu in lane, and I got to have FUN while doing it. If I tried that shit in draft, blind, or teambuilder I'd just get facerolled on by zeds and rivens and have Lee Sins throwing out more Qs than a carny throws knifes, even if I did GOOD it wouldn't be fuckin FUN

It says volumes when you get stuck with "shitty" champions only to realize that when you can't pick any of the top tier champions that they are actually not that bad.  I couldn't decide which champions to ban and give the enemy in Nemesis because when all champions are "bottom tier" they are actually on a level playing field.

It just goes to show you how far ahead the LCS picks are from the rest of the champion pool.

Yeah, unless something fairly substantial changes in RIOT's approach to balance, I'm pretty sure I'll be off to HotS when it comes out. I think at this point I'd rather take a more casual MOBA than one that's so imbalanced.

* Versatility **SHOULD NOT **have more power.
* Versatility **SHOULD **have a limit.
* There **SHOULD NOT** be a lot of versatile champs in the roster.
* There **SHOULD NOT** be a more than just a very small group of champs with low cd and no resource.
* Kit size **SHOULD **be regulated, having kits that are twice as big as others is just disgusting.
* There **SHOULD **be more identity to champs' spells, rather than just more damage, better cc etc.
* There **SHOULD **be some proper balance between ranged and melee by now, ranged **SHOULD **die when approached by melee and melee **SHOULD **die if they don't make ways around to reach ranged.
* There **SHOULD NOT** be any more knee jerk nerfs and buffs.
* Games **SHOULD **start in champion selection it's just not the end of it. We still need counterpicking, counterbuilding and counterplaying, properly outlined *strengths *and *weaknesses *like you know, most of the old champs?

Last but not least, Riot **SHOULD **stick with their design and balancing philosophy, instead of making exceptions everywhere. BE CONSISTENT.

Oh before I forget, Riot **SHOULD ** teach CertainlyT what it means to design a team game champion, he lives in the wrong genre.
